content.content:
Client Information: Auto populated


Session Details:

  • Session times must be adjusted to reflect the actual session length.

  • Session length must reflect the accurate procedure code.

  • If session length changes/is cut short, you must change the procedure code both in the note and in the calendar booking.


Current Diagnosis:

  • Auto-populated.

  • If diagnosis is changed, the treatment plan must be updated.


Current Risk:

**IF INCREASE IN RISK, RISK ASSESSMENT AND CORRESPONDING INTERVENTION MUST HAPPEN BEFORE PROCEEDING WITH THE SESSION 


Client's Subjective Report with Symptom Check-In:

  • Ask yourself: What symptoms are the client reporting that make this session a medically necessary service that insurance will cover?

  • List current symptoms reported and medically relevant mental health updates. 

  • Can be a quote from the client, if it is clinically relevant.

  • Questions that can help determine this include: 

    • How have you been since the last session? 

    • How has your mood been? 

    • If relevant, ask how has your anxiety and depression been (or other relevant/significant symptoms)? 

  • This section does not include detailed client updates that are not clinically relevant (not relevant to treatment plan (diagnosis, associated symptoms, treatment objectives) e.g: “I had vanilla ice cream for dessert today.”

  • Symptoms reported during the session may also be added, and is not limited to the initial check-in.


Clinical Observations:

  • Mark relevant observations.

  • Ensure that it is congruent with subjective report and symptom check-in (For example, if client states, “I am depressed,” the mood selected must correlate). 


Relevant Content (Objective Information Discussed During Session):

  • Ask yourself as a mental health professional: What evidence based interventions am I using this session to treat the diagnosis and symptoms listed on the treatment plan that insurance will cover?

  • This section does not include a detailed narrative/script of the events of the session and does not include information that is not clinically relevant.

    • This section does not focus on what the client reports, but rather on what the professional is doing to treat the client.

  • This section is generally between 4-6 topics and/or interventions from the clinicians perspective. (How did you intervene as a professional clinician in the session to treat the client’s symptoms/diagnosis and progress the client toward treatment goals/objectives). 

  • Topics and intervention should address symptoms and corresponding diagnosis, as much as possible.

  • Topics and symptoms should aim to address concerns and symptoms listed in the subjective report/symptom check-in section.

  • This section includes content that is clinically relevant only.


Interventions Used:

  • Interventions mentioned should correspond with topics and interventions listed in the relevant content section.

  • Supportive reflection and rapport building interventions cannot be the only interventions selected.

  • At least 3 interventions should be listed

  • Only list interventions that you are trained to provide. For example, do not list EMDR if you are not EMDR trained.


Treatment Objectives:

  • Objectives are auto populated and are drawn from the treatment plan. 

  • They cannot be added or changed in the note. 

  • To change the treatment plan objectives, you MUST complete a new treatment plan in the client's file.

  • If there is no treatment plan completed yet (due to the first few sessions), this section should state (or something similar to), “Treatment plan not yet completed, due to early treatment.”


Treatment Plan Progress: 

Progress can be indicated in the following ways:

  • You can document an improvement in symptoms, an increase in symptoms, or no change.

  • If no treatment plan is on file yet (due to the first few sessions), then you can write, “Clinician has yet to complete treatment plan, due to early treatment.”

  • You can document progress toward the treatment plan.

  • You can document progress toward treatment objectives. 

  • Include: progress, lack of progress, maintaining progress, inconsistent progress, regressed

  • Sample Language: Progress as evidenced by; Progressing as evidenced by; Not progressing as evidenced by; Improved the following symptoms; Client is responding well to interventions; Continues to struggle with, etc. 


Plan:

  • Indicate next scheduled session. 

  • Indicate planned interventions or clinically relevant client goals/homework.

sample_notes.content:
Sample Progress Note

Client Information: Auto-populated.

Session Details:

  • Session Time: 10:00 AM - 10:45 AM (45 minutes)

  • Procedure Code: 90834

  • Session Length: 45 minutes

  • Adjustments: None; session length and procedure code align.

Current Diagnosis:

  • F33.1: Major Depressive Disorder, Recurrent, Moderate

  • F41.1: Generalized Anxiety Disorder

Note: Diagnoses reviewed; no changes made during this session.

Current Risk:

  • No increase in risk reported or observed during this session.

Client's Subjective Report with Symptom Check-In:

  • Client reports: “I’ve been feeling a little better since last week, but mornings are still hard. I’m waking up with a lot of anxiety.”

  • Symptoms reported: Persistent low mood, occasional tearfulness, difficulty concentrating, morning anxiety (rated 6/10 by client), and improved ability to complete daily tasks compared to the previous week.

  • Client notes mild improvement in sleep quality with new bedtime routine.

Clinical Observations:

  • Affect: Congruent with mood; mildly dysphoric but more engaged than previous sessions.

  • Appearance: Well-groomed.

  • Behavior: Cooperative and attentive throughout the session.

  • Speech: Clear and normal in rate and tone.

Relevant Content (Objective Information Discussed During Session):

  1. Explored client’s morning routine and identified specific triggers contributing to anxiety.

  2. Explored emotional challenges stemming from interpersonal stress at work and identified potential coping strategies.

  3. Utilized cognitive restructuring techniques to challenge and reframe negative automatic thoughts about productivity.

  4. Educated the client on diaphragmatic breathing techniques to manage acute anxiety symptoms.

  5. Discussed self-compassion strategies to address feelings of guilt around “not doing enough” during difficult mornings.

  6. Reviewed progress on last session’s homework of journaling nightly reflections; identified patterns of improvement and areas for further focus.

Interventions Used:

  1. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT): Focused on challenging negative thought patterns.

  2. Psychoeducation: Taught diaphragmatic breathing for anxiety management.

  3. Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction (MBSR): Introduced grounding techniques to help reduce anxiety triggers.

  4. Supportive Counseling: Validated client’s experiences and encouraged continued use of coping strategies.

Treatment Objectives:

  • Objective 1: Reduce reported symptoms of morning anxiety from 6/10 to 4/10 within six months.

  • Objective 2: Reduce feelings of “worthlessness” from nearly every day to three times a week within six months.

  • Objective 3: Increase verbalizing hopeful, positive statements regarding self and future to at least three times weekly within six months.

  • Objective 4: Reduce “crying spells” from nearly every day to three times a week within six months.

  • Objective 5: Decrease PHQ-9 score from 19 to 14 within six months.

Progress: Client has begun implementing strategies discussed and reports mild but consistent improvement.

Treatment Plan Progress:

  • Progress as evidenced by client’s increased engagement in daily tasks and use of journaling for reflection.

  • Client is responding positively to CBT and mindfulness interventions.

  • Anxiety symptoms are beginning to improve, particularly in the evenings.

  • Continuing to struggle with morning anxiety but is demonstrating willingness to apply new skills.

Plan:

  • Next scheduled session: 09/25/2024 at 10:00 AM.

  • Homework: Continue journaling reflections nightly with added focus on morning anxiety triggers; practice diaphragmatic breathing daily.

  • Planned interventions: Further CBT to address cognitive distortions; introduce progressive muscle relaxation techniques to aid in morning routine stabilization.

notes.content: Wind: 18-22 knots, waves 2-3 feet. Focused on improving my gybe transitions. Successfully completed 3 planing gybes out of 10 attempts. Better sail control during the turn.
notes.feedback: Decent note. Could use some refinement.
notes.improvedNote: Wind: 18-22 knots, waves 2-3 feet. Focused on improving my gybe transitions. Successfully completed 3 planing gybes out of 10 attempts. Better sail control during the turn.

notes.content: Went windsurfing today. Had some fun but struggled with gybes.
notes.feedback:
79
  • Good inclusion of wind conditions
  • Include more details about conditions
  • Describe what you specifically practiced

[Add detailed conditions here]

Practice Focus:

[Describe specific techniques practiced]

Progress:

[Note specific improvements or challenges]

notes.content: Wind: 18-22 knots, waves 2-3 feet. Practiced gybe transitions, focusing on foot placement and sail handling. Made progress with smoother transitions, completing 3 planing gybes out of 10 attempts. Better sail control during the turn phase.
notes.feedback:
82
  • Good inclusion of wind conditions
  • Clear progress indicators
notes.improvedNote: Wind: 18-22 knots, waves 2-3 feet. Practiced gybe transitions, focusing on foot placement and sail handling. Made progress with smoother transitions, completing 3 planing gybes out of 10 attempts. Better sail control during the turn phase.
